newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: ING says not eyeing big acquisition.
newsitem.headline: ING says not eyeing big acquisition.

text.p: Dutch financial services group ING Groep NV is not considering a major acquisition although it can afford to expand in its core businesses of banking and insurance, executive board chairman Aad Jacobs said on Thursday.
Nothing that ING was named almost every day as a possible buyer in both sectors around the world, he said this reputation was unfounded as it was actually very selective.
Indicating the group's financial capacity, he said capital and surplus rose about 10 billion guilders ($5.4 billion) in calendar 1996, helped by buoyant sharemarkets and retained earnings.
ING had the capacity to buy both an insurance company and a bank but any large acquisition would have to make a positive contribution to earnings.
"This company is fortunately rich enough to afford to make acquisitions on both sides," Jacobs said in an interview.
"We have no important acquisitions in mind at this moment. Of course, we are always looking around but there's nothing special on our minds."
ING, which is interested in making a U.S. acquisition, last year missed out on buying insurer First Colony, which was sold to a rival bidder for $1.8 billion.
"But there are many insurance companies in the U.S,." said Jacobs.
Outlining the Dutch group's offshore expansion plans, he said ING would continue to establish "greenfield" insurance operations and build its banking network.
He saw the Far East, Latin America and Eastern Europe as growth areas but declined to say which was most attractive.
"In all of these areas, we are very well placed for growth," said Jacobs.
But in Asia, few acquisition opportunities were available and, where they were, asking prices were too high.
